questions.question: UCC Article 2 applies to:

options.B: Contracts for the sale of goods

questions.explanation: UCC Article 2 governs contracts for the sale of goods—tangible, movable personal property. It does not apply to real estate, services, or intangibles. For mixed contracts (goods and services), courts often apply Article 2 if goods are the predominant purpose.
questions.tip: Article 2 = goods (tangible, movable). Services = common law. Mixed contracts = predominant purpose test.

questions.question: Under the UCC, a merchant's firm offer is irrevocable for:

options.A: 30 days or the time stated, whichever is shorter
options.B: Up to 3 months even without consideration
options.D: The time stated in the offer only

questions.explanation: A merchant's written, signed offer to buy or sell goods that assures it will be held open is irrevocable for the time stated or a reasonable time, but not exceeding 3 months, without consideration. This is the firm offer rule unique to UCC Article 2.
questions.tip: Firm offer: merchant, written, signed, assures open. Max 3 months. No consideration needed.

questions.question: Under UCC Article 2, a contract for the sale of goods must be in writing if the price is:

options.B: $500 or more

questions.explanation: The UCC Statute of Frauds requires contracts for the sale of goods priced at $500 or more to be in writing. The writing must indicate a contract for sale, be signed by the party to be charged, and specify quantity. Exceptions include specially manufactured goods, admissions, and part performance.
questions.tip: $500 threshold for goods. Writing needs: contract exists, signature, quantity. Price/other terms can be missing.

questions.question: The implied warranty of merchantability applies when:

options.B: A merchant sells goods of a kind they regularly deal in

questions.explanation: The implied warranty of merchantability arises automatically when a merchant sells goods of the kind they regularly deal in. Goods must be fit for ordinary purposes, of fair average quality, and properly packaged and labeled. Non-merchants don't make this warranty.
questions.tip: Merchantability: merchant seller + goods they deal in. Goods must be fit for ordinary purpose.

questions.question: Under FOB shipping point, risk of loss passes to the buyer when:

options.B: The seller delivers the goods to the carrier

questions.explanation: FOB (Free on Board) shipping point means risk of loss passes when the seller delivers conforming goods to the carrier at the shipping point. The buyer bears risk during transit. FOB destination means risk passes when goods reach the buyer's location.
questions.tip: FOB shipping point: risk passes at shipment (seller done when given to carrier). FOB destination: risk passes on arrival.

questions.question: When a seller breaches by failing to deliver goods, the buyer may:

options.B: Cover by purchasing substitute goods and recover damages
options.C: Demand specific performance in all cases

questions.explanation: When the seller fails to deliver or delivers non-conforming goods, the buyer can cover (buy substitute goods) and recover the difference between cover price and contract price, plus incidental and consequential damages. Cover must be reasonable and in good faith.
questions.tip: Cover = buy substitute goods. Damages = cover price - contract price. Must act in good faith.

questions.question: Under UCC Section 2-207, when an acceptance contains additional terms:

options.B: Between merchants, additional terms become part of the contract unless they materially alter it
options.C: The additional terms are always included

questions.explanation: Section 2-207 allows contract formation even when acceptance differs from the offer. Between merchants, additional terms become part of the contract unless: (1) the offer limits acceptance to its terms, (2) the terms materially alter the contract, or (3) the offeror objects within a reasonable time.
questions.tip: 2-207: definite acceptance + different terms = contract. Additional terms: merchants = included unless material alteration.

questions.conceptTested: Warranty of fitness for particular purpose
questions.question: The implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arises when:

options.B: The seller knows the buyer's particular purpose and buyer relies on seller's skill to select
options.C: Goods are used for their ordinary purpose

questions.explanation: The warranty of fitness for a particular purpose arises when: (1) the seller knows or has reason to know the buyer's particular purpose, and (2) the buyer relies on the seller's skill or judgment to select suitable goods. Any seller (not just merchants) can make this warranty.
questions.tip: Fitness: seller knows purpose + buyer relies on seller's expertise. Any seller (not just merchants).

questions.question: Under the perfect tender rule, if goods fail to conform to the contract in any respect, the buyer may:

options.A: Only accept the goods with a price reduction
options.B: Reject the whole, accept the whole, or accept any commercial units and reject the rest
options.D: Accept but must pay full price

questions.explanation: The UCC's perfect tender rule allows the buyer to reject goods if they fail to conform in any respect. The buyer can reject the whole delivery, accept the whole, or accept any commercial units and reject the rest. Rejection must be within a reasonable time after delivery.
questions.tip: Perfect tender: any non-conformity = right to reject (whole, part, or none). Limited by cure rights and installment contracts.

questions.question: A seller's right to cure a non-conforming tender exists when:

options.A: The buyer has already resold the goods
options.B: The time for performance has not expired or seller had reason to believe tender was acceptable
options.C: The goods were destroyed in transit
options.D: The contract is silent on remedies

questions.explanation: The seller has the right to cure if: (1) time for performance hasn't expired, or (2) the seller had reasonable grounds to believe the tender would be acceptable (e.g., prior course of dealing). The seller must notify the buyer of intent to cure and make a conforming delivery.
questions.tip: Cure: before deadline always. After deadline only if seller reasonably believed goods acceptable.

questions.question: To disclaim the implied warranty of merchantability, the seller must:

options.B: Mention merchantability specifically, and if in writing, make it conspicuous
options.C: Obtain signed waiver from the buyer

questions.explanation: To disclaim merchantability, the disclaimer must specifically mention 'merchantability' and, if in writing, must be conspicuous (noticeable to a reasonable person). 'As is' or 'with all faults' language disclaims all implied warranties. Fitness for particular purpose requires a conspicuous writing.
questions.tip: Merchantability disclaimer: must say 'merchantability' + conspicuous if written. 'As is' disclaims all implied warranties.

questions.question: If a buyer breaches after goods are identified to the contract:

options.A: Risk of loss remains with seller until cure
options.B: Risk of loss may shift to breaching buyer to extent of any insurance deficiency

questions.explanation: When the buyer breaches as to goods already identified to the contract, risk of loss remains with the seller. However, if the goods are damaged or destroyed, the seller can treat the risk of loss as having rested on the buyer to the extent of any deficiency in the seller's insurance coverage.
questions.tip: Breach affects risk: breaching party may bear uninsured risk. Protects innocent party's insurance coverage.

questions.question: When a buyer wrongfully rejects goods, the seller may:

options.A: Only sue for the contract price
options.B: Resell the goods and recover the difference plus damages

questions.explanation: When the buyer breaches, the seller can resell the goods in a commercially reasonable manner and recover the difference between the resale price and contract price, plus incidental damages. Alternatively, the seller can sue for market price damages or, in some cases, the contract price.
questions.tip: Seller's resale: contract price - resale price + incidentals. Must be commercially reasonable. Alternative: market price damages.

questions.question: In an installment contract, the buyer can reject an installment only if:

options.A: Any defect exists in the installment
options.B: The non-conformity substantially impairs that installment and cannot be cured
options.C: The seller has breached in prior installments
options.D: The buyer provides written notice within 24 hours

questions.explanation: For installment contracts, the perfect tender rule is relaxed. The buyer can reject an installment only if the non-conformity substantially impairs that installment and cannot be cured. The buyer can cancel the whole contract only if non-conformity substantially impairs the whole contract.
questions.tip: Installment: substantial impairment test, not perfect tender. Whole contract breach requires impairment of entire deal.

questions.question: An express warranty is created by:

options.A: The seller's statement of opinion about the goods
options.B: Any affirmation of fact, description, or sample that becomes part of the basis of the bargain
options.C: The implied course of dealing only
options.D: All goods being sold at retail

questions.explanation: Express warranties are created by: (1) affirmations of fact or promise regarding the goods, (2) descriptions of the goods, or (3) samples or models, if they become part of the basis of the bargain. Seller's opinions or puffing ('best in town') don't create warranties.
questions.tip: Express warranty: fact, description, sample. Must be 'basis of bargain.' Opinion/puffing = no warranty.

questions.question: A purchaser with voidable title can transfer good title to:

options.B: A good faith purchaser for value

questions.explanation: A person with voidable title (obtained through fraud, bounced check, or minor's sale) can transfer good title to a good faith purchaser for value (BFP). The original owner's recourse is against the wrongdoer, not the BFP. Void title (theft) cannot be transferred even to a BFP.
questions.tip: Voidable title: BFP gets good title. Void title (theft): no one gets good title. BFP = good faith + value.

questions.question: Acceptance of goods occurs when the buyer:

options.B: Signifies acceptance, fails to reject after reasonable opportunity, or does any act inconsistent with seller's ownership

questions.explanation: Acceptance occurs when buyer: (1) signifies the goods are conforming or will be accepted despite non-conformity, (2) fails to make an effective rejection after a reasonable opportunity to inspect, or (3) does any act inconsistent with the seller's ownership. Acceptance obligates the buyer to pay.
questions.tip: Acceptance: signify conformity, fail to reject, or inconsistent act. Once accepted, can't reject (but can revoke in limited cases).

questions.question: A buyer may obtain specific performance when:

options.B: The goods are unique or in other proper circumstances
options.D: The market price exceeds the contract price

questions.explanation: Specific performance is available when goods are unique (art, antiques, custom goods) or in other proper circumstances where damages would be inadequate. The UCC liberalizes the common law rule. Requirements contracts for essential goods may also qualify.
questions.tip: Specific performance: unique goods or inadequate damages. UCC more liberal than common law.

questions.question: In a requirements contract, the quantity term is:

options.B: The buyer's actual requirements occurring in good faith
options.C: Whatever the buyer wants to order
options.D: Fixed at the average of prior purchases

questions.explanation: Requirements and output contracts are valid under the UCC despite lack of a fixed quantity. The quantity is the buyer's actual requirements (or seller's output) occurring in good faith. Quantities cannot be unreasonably disproportionate to stated estimates or prior comparable requirements.
questions.tip: Requirements: buyer's good faith needs. Output: seller's good faith production. Cannot be unreasonably disproportionate to estimates.

questions.question: Under the entrustment rule, if an owner entrusts goods to a merchant who deals in goods of that kind:

options.A: The merchant can never sell the goods
options.B: The merchant can transfer all rights the entruster had to a buyer in ordinary course
options.C: The owner loses all claims to the goods
options.D: Only the entruster can authorize sale

questions.explanation: Entrustment to a merchant who deals in goods of that kind gives the merchant power to transfer all rights of the entruster to a buyer in the ordinary course of business. The original owner can sue the merchant for conversion but cannot recover the goods from the BIOC.
questions.tip: Entrustment: BIOC gets good title from merchant. Owner's remedy is against merchant, not buyer.

questions.question: Under the UCC, liquidated damages clauses are enforceable if they are:

options.A: Agreed to by both parties regardless of amount
options.B: Reasonable in light of anticipated or actual harm
options.C: Equal to at least 10% of the contract price

questions.explanation: Liquidated damages are enforceable if reasonable in light of anticipated or actual harm caused by breach, the difficulties of proof of loss, and the inconvenience of otherwise obtaining a remedy. Unreasonably large liquidated damages are void as a penalty.
questions.tip: Liquidated damages: must be reasonable estimate of harm. Penalty clauses unenforceable.

questions.question: Between merchants, a written confirmation of an oral contract:

options.A: Has no effect on the Statute of Frauds
options.B: Satisfies the Statute of Frauds against the sender only
options.C: Satisfies the Statute of Frauds against both parties if not objected to within 10 days
options.D: Must be signed by both parties

questions.explanation: Between merchants, a written confirmation sent within a reasonable time that is sufficient against the sender satisfies the Statute of Frauds against the recipient unless written notice of objection is given within 10 days of receipt. This is the merchant's confirmatory memo rule.
questions.tip: Merchant confirmation: binds recipient unless they object in writing within 10 days. Only between merchants.

questions.question: A buyer may revoke acceptance of goods when:

options.B: Non-conformity substantially impairs value and was accepted on assumption of cure or without knowledge due to difficulty of discovery
options.C: The buyer changes their mind within 30 days
options.D: The market price drops below contract price

questions.explanation: Revocation of acceptance requires: (1) non-conformity that substantially impairs value to the buyer, (2) acceptance was either on reasonable assumption of cure or without discovery of defect due to difficulty of discovery or seller's assurances, and (3) revocation within a reasonable time after discovery.
questions.tip: Revocation: substantial impairment + accepted under reasonable belief of cure or hidden defect. Higher standard than rejection.

questions.question: In a sale on approval:

options.A: Risk of loss passes immediately to the buyer
options.B: Title and risk remain with seller until buyer accepts
options.D: Creditors of the buyer can immediately attach the goods

questions.explanation: In a sale on approval (goods delivered for buyer's use/trial), title and risk remain with the seller until the buyer accepts. The buyer can return conforming goods at the seller's risk and expense. The goods are not subject to claims of the buyer's creditors until acceptance.
questions.tip: Sale on approval: for buyer's use, risk with seller. Sale or return: for resale, risk with buyer. Key distinction!

questions.question: Under the UCC, warranty protection extends to:

options.B: Persons in the buyer's household or guests who suffer physical injury (at minimum)

questions.explanation: The UCC offers three alternative provisions for privity. The least expansive (Alternative A) extends warranty protection to family, household members, or guests of the buyer who may reasonably be expected to use the goods and suffer personal injury. States may adopt broader alternatives.
questions.tip: Privity: UCC relaxes for third party beneficiaries. Minimum = household + guests for personal injury. States vary.

questions.question: When a party to a sales contract clearly indicates they will not perform before performance is due:

options.A: The other party must wait until the due date to act
options.B: The aggrieved party may suspend performance and await performance or resort to remedies for breach

questions.explanation: Anticipatory repudiation occurs when a party indicates they won't perform before performance is due. The aggrieved party may: (1) await performance for a commercially reasonable time, (2) resort to any remedy for breach, or (3) suspend their own performance. The repudiating party can retract if the other hasn't acted in reliance.
questions.tip: Anticipatory breach: can await or act on breach immediately. Repudiation can be retracted before reliance or cancellation.

questions.question: Consequential damages are recoverable by the buyer when:

options.B: The seller had reason to know of the buyer's particular requirements and damages couldn't be prevented
options.C: The buyer requested them in the contract

questions.explanation: Consequential damages include losses the seller had reason to know would result from the breach (e.g., lost profits, injury) and that could not reasonably be prevented by cover or otherwise. Incidental damages (inspection, storage, shipping costs) are recoverable without this foreseeability requirement.
questions.tip: Consequential: foreseeable losses that couldn't be mitigated. Incidental: costs of dealing with breach. Sellers can limit consequential damages.

questions.question: Under the UCC, a contract modification:

options.A: Requires new consideration to be enforceable
options.B: Is enforceable without consideration if made in good faith
options.D: Is void if it increases the price

questions.explanation: Unlike common law, UCC contract modifications don't require consideration—good faith is sufficient. However, if the contract as modified falls within the Statute of Frauds ($500+), the modification must be in writing. A no-oral-modification clause can require written modifications.
questions.tip: UCC modification: no consideration needed, just good faith. Written if over $500 or NOM clause exists.

questions.question: A seller is excused from performance under commercial impracticability when:

options.A: Performance becomes more expensive than anticipated
options.B: An unforeseen contingency makes performance impracticable, and the seller complies with allocation duties

questions.explanation: Commercial impracticability excuses performance when: (1) performance is made impracticable, (2) by an event the non-occurrence of which was a basic assumption of the contract, and (3) without fault of the seller. If only part of capacity is affected, the seller must allocate fairly among customers.
questions.tip: Impracticability: unforeseen event + impracticable (not just expensive). Must allocate available supply fairly.

questions.question: An unpaid seller can reclaim goods from an insolvent buyer if:

options.B: Demand is made within a reasonable time after the seller discovers insolvency (or 10 days for cash sale)
options.D: The buyer fails to respond to invoices

questions.explanation: A seller can reclaim goods from an insolvent buyer who received goods on credit if demand is made within a reasonable time after the seller discovers insolvency. For cash sales (payment due on delivery), the seller can reclaim within 10 days of delivery. BFP's rights cut off reclamation.
questions.tip: Reclamation: insolvency + reasonable time demand. Cash sale = 10 days. BFP defeats reclamation right.

questions.question: A contract for the sale of goods with an open price term is:

options.B: Valid if the parties intend to be bound, with price to be a reasonable price
options.C: Enforceable only if price is determined within 10 days

questions.explanation: The UCC allows contracts with open terms if the parties intend to make a contract. An open price means a reasonable price at the time of delivery. Other terms that can be left open include: place of delivery (seller's place), time of payment (delivery), and time of delivery (reasonable time).
questions.tip: Open terms OK if intent to contract. Price = reasonable. Delivery = seller's place. Time = reasonable. Only quantity must be stated.

questions.question: For risk of loss rules to apply, goods must be:

options.B: Identified to the contract

questions.explanation: Goods must be identified to the contract before risk of loss can pass. Identification occurs when specific goods are designated as those to which the contract refers. This can happen at contracting (existing goods), when goods are shipped/marked (fungible), or when crops are planted/animals conceived.
questions.tip: Identification = these specific goods for this contract. Risk rules don't apply until goods are identified.

questions.question: A seller may recover the full contract price when:

options.A: The buyer simply refuses to pay
options.B: Goods are accepted, lost/damaged after risk passed, or cannot be resold at reasonable price
options.C: The market price is lower than contract price

questions.explanation: The seller can recover the price when: (1) the buyer accepted the goods, (2) conforming goods are lost or damaged after risk passed to buyer, or (3) the goods cannot be resold at a reasonable price after reasonable effort. In other cases, the seller is limited to damages (contract-market or contract-resale).
questions.tip: Price action: acceptance, risk passed, or can't resell. Otherwise seller must prove damages, not collect full price.

questions.question: In an auction sale, unless announced otherwise, the auction is:

options.B: With reserve, allowing the auctioneer to withdraw goods before the hammer falls
options.D: Subject to a 24-hour cooling off period

questions.explanation: Unless specifically announced as 'without reserve,' auctions are with reserve. In with reserve auctions, the auctioneer may withdraw goods at any time before the hammer falls. In without reserve auctions, once the auctioneer calls for bids, the goods cannot be withdrawn unless no bid is received in reasonable time.
questions.tip: Default = with reserve (auctioneer can withdraw). Without reserve must be announced (can't withdraw after calling for bids).

questions.question: A party with reasonable grounds for insecurity may:

options.B: Demand adequate assurance of performance and suspend if assurance not provided within 30 days

questions.explanation: When reasonable grounds for insecurity arise regarding the other party's performance, the insecure party may demand adequate assurance of due performance in writing. The demanding party may suspend their own performance until assurance is received. Failure to provide adequate assurance within 30 days is a repudiation.
questions.tip: Demand assurance: must be in writing. No response in 30 days = repudiation. Can suspend pending assurance.
